abstract: Apple cut the price of its iPhone by $200 to $199, but AT&T is raising price of the data service you need to use the phone to $30 a month — a $10 increase. In other words, consumers will wind up paying $40 more over the course of two years than they would have under the previous iPhone deal.
snippet: Apple cut the price of its iPhone by $200 to $199, but AT&T is raising price of the data service you need to use the phone to $30 a month — a $10 increase. In other words, consumers will wind up paying $40 more over the course of two years than th...
lead_paragraph: The biggest news from Apple is what Steve Jobs didn’t say: It has completely changed the basis of its deals with AT&T and other wireless carriers.

headline.main: The Cost of the $199 iPhone: $10 More a Month for Data

abstract: Sprint is aggressively positioning its upcoming Samsung Instinct smart phone as an alternative to Apple’s upgraded iPhone.
snippet: Sprint is aggressively positioning its upcoming Samsung Instinct smart phone as an alternative to Apple’s upgraded iPhone.
lead_paragraph: (UPDATED 6/11/08 5:35 p.m.: David Pogue reviews the Samsung Instinct.)

headline.main: Basic Instinct: Sprint Battles AT&T and iPhone With New Samsung Device

abstract: In Sunday’s New York Times, Bill Carter interviews Thom Beers, a television producer called “the P. T. Barnum of nonfiction television” by John Ford, the president of the Discovery Channel.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s New York Times, Bill Carter interviews Thom Beers, a television producer called “the P. T. Barnum of nonfiction television” by John Ford, the president of the Discovery Channel.

abstract: AT&T is trying to wean corporate customers from their BlackBerries with the new iPhone model, but even if the phone giant fails, it wins — it sells both.
snippet: AT&T is trying to wean corporate customers from their BlackBerries with the new iPhone model, but even if the phone giant fails, it wins — it sells both.
lead_paragraph: To hear AT&T executives tell it, the company expects the iPhone to strike at the heart of the BlackBerry, taking aim at business customers who have been devoted fans of the so-called “CrackBerry” for years.

headline.main: AT&T Targets Business Customers With iPhone

abstract: Ralph de la Vega, chief executive of AT&T, said that the carrier’s deal with Apple was changed because a $199 upfront price will attract a lot more customers. Existing iPhone users are welcome to upgrade, but if they do, they won’t be able to get a subsidized price again for two years.
snippet: Ralph de la Vega, chief executive of AT&T, said that the carrier’s deal with Apple was changed because a $199 upfront price will attract a lot more customers. Existing iPhone users are welcome to upgrade, but if they do, they won’t be able to get ...
lead_paragraph: AT&T restructured its deal with Apple, said Ralph de la Vega, the chief executive of AT&T Mobility, in order to overcome resistance from mass consumers to the high $399 price of the iPhone. Now, instead of paying Apple a portion of their monthly fees, carriers like AT&T will make a large payment to Apple every time an iPhone is sold and attached to their network.

headline.main: AT&T: New Low Price Will Move iPhones to Mass Market
